page.title: 09SMALLFIELD VILLAGE
page.content: { Smallfield village}is an example of Victorian linear development. This has been broadened by housing estates built during the last 30 years. Smallfield has retained its village identity despite being almost a suburb of Horley. The village centre has a Post Office, Church hall and a few shops. There are infrequent bus services to Horley, Crawley and East Grinstead. The name "Smallfield" is thought to be derived from the "Small Field" once part of the Common extending east towards Horne. The school now stands on the "Small Field" which was eventually enclosed and farmed for hay. Being in the lowest lying part of the area and liable to flooding, only one hay crop a year could be grown. The village Church lies 1 mile south in the hamlet of Burstow.
